diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or internal organs. Symptoms go through cycles of flare-ups and remissions and can include fever, rash, arthritis, and in some cases, psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms include fever, painful and tender joints (polyarthritis), heart inflammation, and a characteristic rash known as erythema marginatum.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis (Secondary Stage)
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact. The disease starts as a painless sore and progresses to the secondary stage, characterized by skin rash and mucous membrane lesions. Untreated syphilis can eventually cause damage to multiple organ systems including the brain.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and joint pain. Some people also develop synovitis. Fever and a distinctive salmon-colored bumpy rash are classic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease (Late Stage)
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by ticks. Early signs include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans. If untreated, the infection can spread to the joints, heart, and nervous system, leading to more severe problems.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya
diagnoses.description: A viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. Symptoms include fever, joint pain, and rash. Although most patients recover fully, in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. The condition can affect adults and children, and its exact cause is unknown. Symptoms include violet or dusky red rash and progressive muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's most commonly seen in children. The primary signs include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, red eyes, lips, and throat, and swollen lymph glands.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the formation of granulomas, non-cancerous tumors. Symptoms can include fatigue, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and a rash.

diagnoses.name: Leptospirosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial disease that affects humans and animals. It is caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. In humans, it can cause a wide range of symptoms, some of which may be mistaken for other diseases. In severe cases, it can cause kidney damage, meningitis, liver failure, and respiratory distress.

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., Viral or bacterial infection causing reactive arthritis or pleuritis)
Viral infections (e.g., dengue fever, Zika virus)
PANDAS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal Infections)

diagnoses.explanation: Anxiety can manifest through a variety of symptoms, including hyperactivity, obsessive-compulsive behavior, and even chest pain due to increased heart rate and stress. While it does not directly cause endometriosis or weight gain, stress and hormonal imbalances associated with severe anxiety might influence weight fluctuations.

Depression can manifest in increased weight due to changes in appetite or eating habits, obsessive-compulsive behavior as a coping mechanism, and somatic symptoms such as chest pain. It doesn’t directly cause endometriosis, but chronic stress and depression can exacerbate endometriosis symptoms.

OCD could explain the presence of obsessive-compulsive behaviors, and some patients may experience hyperactivity or agitation. OCD-related stress and anxiety might contribute to somatic symptoms like chest pain but does not directly link to endometriosis or weight gain.

PCOS is associated with weight gain and can have side effects that might mimic or exacerbate endometriosis symptoms due to hormonal imbalances, although it does not cause hyperactivity, chest pain, or obsessive-compulsive behavior directly.

Thyroid disorders, particularly hypothyroidism, can cause weight gain and may lead to increased levels of anxiety, which could manifest as hyperactivity or obsessive-compulsive behaviors. It does not directly cause endometriosis or chest pain, though thyroid disease can affect overall energy levels and mood.

General hormonal imbalances can lead to or worsen conditions like endometriosis and contribute to weight gain. While they may not directly cause hyperactivity or obsessive-compulsive behavior, hormonal fluctuations can impact mood and anxiety levels, potentially resulting in these symptoms.

PMDD could explain severe mood-related symptoms, including anxiety that manifests as hyperactivity or obsessive thoughts. It’s associated with the menstrual cycle and thus could indirectly relate to endometriosis symptoms worsening, alongside general weight gain. However, it does not directly cause chest pain.

While primarily associated with chest pain due to reduced blood flow to the heart, CAD doesn’t directly cause the other symptoms but could lead to increased anxiety or stress over health concerns, potentially triggering or exacerbating symptoms like hyperactivity and obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

Eating disorders can lead to significant weight gain or loss and are often associated with obsessive-compulsive behavior. The stress and anxiety surrounding eating could manifest as hyperactivity. These disorders don’t cause endometriosis or directly lead to chest pain, but the stress on the body might exacerbate such symptoms indirectly.

Fibromyalgia is associated with widespread pain, including chest pain, and can affect individuals’ weight due to activity level changes or medication side effects. The condition is often comorbid with anxiety disorders, which could explain hyperactivity and obsessive-compulsive behaviors but is not directly linked to endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Upper respiratory infection
diagnoses.description: An infection that affects the nose, throat, and airways, which can lead to symptoms like coughing and frequent waking due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe, leading to coughing and potential sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus), causing cough and possibly affecting taste (dysgeusia).

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the body doesn't have enough iron, leading to symptoms like dysgeusia and possibly menorrhagia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose), potentially leading to dysgeusia and contributing to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive sleep apnea
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder characterized by repeated stopping and starting of breathing, which can cause frequent waking and may be associated with a cough.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, potentially leading to menorrhagia and contributing to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges, which can be associated with menorrhagia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in certain vitamins, such as B12 or zinc, can lead to symptoms like dysgeusia and contribute to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Heart failure
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition where the heart doesn't pump blood as well as it should, which can lead to coughing (especially when lying down) and could indirectly affect sleep.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms including dry eyes and mouth, which could relate to the experienced dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that can manifest physically through symptoms such as sleep disturbance (obstructive sleep apnea), irritability, and changes in sensory perceptions, potentially explaining tinnitus and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can lead to a variety of complications, including neuropathy which might manifest as tinnitus or dysgeusia, and could indirectly contribute to obstructive sleep apnea through weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Mental health conditions that can cause or exacerbate symptoms like irritability, sleep disturbances (including apnea), and dysgeusia due to heightened stress levels.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A deficiency that can cause neurological and psychiatric symptoms, including irritability and tinnitus, as well as potentially contributing to dry eyes and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that can present with general fatigue potentially leading to sleep disturbances, including sleep apnea, and can also cause dry eyes and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism that can present with symptoms of irritability, sleep apnea, dry eyes, and changes in taste or hearing.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body and can also lead to sleep problems, irritability, and sensory symptoms such as dysgeusia and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A mineral deficiency that can cause symptoms like hair loss, diarrhea, and eye and skin lesions, and has been associated with changes in taste (dysgeusia) and possibly contributing to dry eyes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can lead to a wide range of symptoms including sensory disturbances (dysgeusia, tinnitus), fatigue causing sleep disturbances, and emotional changes like irritability.

diagnoses: Autoimmune Diseases such as Lupus or Rheumatoid Arthritis

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a significant increase in heart rate upon standing, often accompanied by symptoms like lightheadedness, fainting, and rapid heartbeat. It might coexist with other systemic symptoms due to its potential underlying causes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and damage in the affected organs. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including lymphadenitis, decreased libido, and potentially hyperferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, this disease is characterized by fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands, and fatigue. It may present with lymphadenitis and could contribute to a state of hyperferritinemia during the acute phase.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder leading to excessive absorption of iron by the body, resulting in hyperferritinemia. It can affect various organs and systems, potentially leading to symptoms such as fatigue, joint pain, and decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer originating from lymphocytes. It can cause symptoms like lymphadenitis, fever, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Hyperferritinemia may also be seen due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: This group of blood cancers develops in the lymphatic system. Symptoms can include swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), fatigue, fever, and possibly hyperferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and decreased libido. It impacts the body's ability to regulate blood pressure and responds to stress, potentially compounding issues like POTS.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, commonly caused by viral, bacterial, or parasitic infections. Symptoms include vomiting, diarrhea, and stomach pain. While not directly related to hyperferritinemia or POTS, complicated cases could present overlapping symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It can present symptoms similar to POTS and is often accompanied by a wide array of nonspecific symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Iron Overload Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from the accumulation of too much iron in the body, potentially leading to hyperferritinemia. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including liver disease, heart problems, and diabetes. While its direct correlation to decreased libido or POTS is less clear, systemic effects can potentially overlap.

diagnoses: Acute abdomen (e.g., appendicitis, diverticulitis, perforated viscus)
Inflammatory bowel disease flare (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction (including allergic and pseudoallergic reactions)
Peanut or other severe food allergies
Toxic ingestion (e.g., alcohol poisoning, exposure to toxic chemicals)
Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Vitamin B12 or Folate Deficiency Anemia
Hepatitis B or C associated vasculitis
